statement:
From the Euler relation

$$e^{i\theta} = \cos \theta + i \sin \theta$$

it follows that

$$\begin{aligned}
e^{i\theta \cdot n} &= (e^{i\theta})^n\\
\cos n \theta + i \sin n \theta &= (\cos \theta + i \sin \theta)^n\end{aligned}$$

where $n\in\mathbb{Z}$. This is called *de Moivre’s formula*, and
besides being generally useful, it’s a convenient way to remember
double- (and higher-multiple-) angle formulas. For example,

$$\cos 2 \theta + i \sin 2 \theta = (\cos \theta + i \sin \theta)^2 = \cos^2 \theta + 2 i \sin \theta \cos \theta - \sin^2 \theta.$$

Since the imaginary parts and real parts on each side must be equal, we
must have $$\cos 2 \theta = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta$$ and
$$\sin 2 \theta = 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta.$$
